TEXT: The applicants in application no . CARDINAL are Mr PERSON and PERSON , NORP nationals who were born in DATE and DATE respectively and live in GPE . They were represented before ORG by PERSON and Mr PERSON , lawyers practising in GPE .
The applicant in application no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL is PERSON , a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

The applicants in application no . CARDINAL are PERSON and PERSON , NORP nationals who were born in DATE and DATE respectively and live in GPE . They were represented before the Court by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .
The facts of the CARDINAL cases under examination , as submitted by the applicants , may be summarised as follows .

The applicants acquired from the ORG apartments that had become ORG property by virtue of the nationalisations carried out by the communist regime in GPE in DATE and the following DATE . The apartments had been nationalised without compensation .

After the adoption of LAW in DATE , in proceedings under section CARDINAL of that law brought by the former pre - nationalisation owners , the applicants’ titles were declared null and void and they were ordered to vacate the apartments .

In DATE , it became possible for the applicants to obtain compensation from the ORG . Compensation was granted in the form of bonds which could be used in privatisation tenders and sold to brokers . Until DATE bonds were traded at price levels CARDINAL of their face value . Their price surged towards DATE and reached PERCENT and more of face value and then fell again . In DATE , it became possible for persons who have not sold their bonds to obtain their full face value directly from the ORG .

The remaining relevant background facts have been summarised in the ORG ’s judgment in the case of ORG and Others v. GPE , nos . CARDINAL , ORG , CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL , GPE , CARDINAL/CARDINAL , ORG , and CARDINAL , DATE .
In the CARDINAL cases under examination , the claims under section CARDINAL of LAW were brought within the relevant DATE time limit after the adoption of that law in DATE .
The grounds on which the applicants’ titles were declared null and void and the relevant circumstances were as follows .

The courts found , in proceedings that ended by final judgment of ORG of DATE , that the applicants had purchased the property at issue ( a storey in a CARDINAL - storey house ) in DATE , at a time when CARDINAL of the applicants owned another property which could satisfy the applicants’ housing need . It followed that the purchase had been in breach of the requirement that only persons who did not own other real property qualified to purchase ORG housing . In the course of the proceedings the courts also dealt with alleged irregularities in respect of tenancy orders dating from DATE and DATE .
The applicants have not informed the ORG whether they have received compensatory bonds or rented or purchased municipal housing .

The courts found , in proceedings that ended by final judgment of ORG DATE , that the apartment in question had exceeded in size the relevant limits fixed by legislation in respect of a CARDINAL - member family , as the applicant ’s at the time of the transaction ( DATE ) . The courts also found that in breach of the relevant law the apartment had not been offered for sale to the tenants who had been living therein , but directly to the applicant , as a former resistance fighter .
In DATE the applicant unsuccessfully attempted to reopen the proceedings . She vacated the apartment on an unspecified date .
In DATE the applicant was temporarily provided with municipal housing for rent at fixed low rates . She remained there at least until DATE .

In DATE the applicant obtained compensatory bonds with face value MONEY ( ORG ) ( the equivalent of approximately ORG CARDINAL ) . The applicant has not informed the ORG whether she had sold her compensatory bonds and if so at what price .

The courts , in proceedings that ended by final judgment of ORG of DATE , found that the applicants had purchased the apartment at issue in DATE , despite the ORG ’s decision of CARDINAL DATE imposing a moratorium on sales of ORG and municipal property .
The applicants have not informed the ORG whether they have received compensatory bonds or rented or purchased municipal housing .
The pre - nationalisation owners brought an action against the applicants on DATE . DATE ORG held CARDINAL hearings and admitted evidence .
The hearing listed for DATE was adjourned as the ORG lawyer had been unable to attend . The next and last hearing was held on DATE .
By judgment of DATE ORG granted the claim against the applicants . They appealed .
ORG held a hearing on DATE .
By judgment of DATE ORG quashed the lower court ’s judgment and rejected the claim .
On DATE the plaintiffs , the pre - nationalisation owners , submitted a petition for review ( cassation ) to ORG .
ORG held a hearing on DATE .
By judgment of DATE ORG quashed ORG judgment and referred the case back to that court .
In the renewed examination of the case by ORG , the hearings listed for DATE and DATE were adjourned at the ORG request .
The court held CARDINAL hearings - on DATE , DATE and DATE .
By judgment of DATE ORG quashed ORG judgment of DATE and referred the case back for renewed examination by that court .
ORG held a hearing on DATE , CARDINAL May and DATE . CARDINAL of the adjournments was caused by the plaintiffs’ failure to submit a relevant document .
By judgment of DATE ORG granted the restitution claim against the applicants . They appealed .
Before ORG , the hearing listed for DATE was adjourned owing to illness of CARDINAL of the applicants .
On DATE ORG noted the applicants’ failure to amend their appeal in accordance with procedural requirements introduced in DATE and instructed them to do so .
At the hearing held on DATE the court heard the parties and admitted evidence , including an expert ’s report .
By judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG upheld the lower court ’s judgment of DATE . The applicants submitted a cassation appeal .
ORG held a hearing on DATE .
By judgment of DATE ORG upheld the lower courts’ judgments of DATE and CARDINAL .
The relevant domestic law and practice have been set out in the ORG ’s judgment in the case of ORG and Others v. GPE , cited above .
